text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
Updated throughout for editorial and plain language changes.
This supersedes IRM 7.11.3 dated July 02,
Tax Exempt and Government Entities Employee Plans
Exempt Quality Measurement System (TEQMS) 7.11.3 page
) Purpose: This IRM describes the Tax Exempt Quality Measurement (TEQMS) and the TEQMS process for Tax Exempt and Government and (TE/GE) Employee Plans (EP) Determinations specialists and managers. (
) Audience: EP Determinations and Quality Assurance (QA) staff (
) Policy Owner: Director, EP (
) Program Owner: EP (

) Program Goals: The goal of EP Determinations is to ensure that plans with the tax laws by reviewing applications for determination letters (DLs) opinion letters, and to protect the public interest by applying the tax law integrity and fairness to all. (

) TEQMS is designed to measure the quality of the work product TE/GE employees demonstrate using established quality criteria and serves as the quality measurement in the business results part of the Balanced Measurement System (BPMS). (
) TEQMS is designed to achieve statistical validity at the national level for Determinations. (
) TEQMS for EP Examinations is in IRM
, TE/GE Examinations, Review (SR) and Tax Exempt Quality Measurement System (TEQMS) dures. (

) This IRM includes: a. Overview of TEQMS. b. Quality Assurance Staff/Role of TEQMS Analyst. c. Case selection process. d. Review and data submission process. e. Tools for assessing data reliability. f. Case return process. (
) IRS’s authority to issue favorable determination letters (DLs) on the status of pension, proﬁt sharing, stock bonus, annuity, and employee stock ownership plans under IRC

Overseeing the TEQMS sample selection process. b. Validating the sample input data from surveys. c. Monitoring case receipts for the sample selection. d. ) EP Determination cases subject to TEQMS review are divided into two EP Determinations management determines the type of cases included in group. a. EP Determination cases, also known as non-merit cases, closed with closing code

Note: The group’s closing code determines the type of review classiﬁcation. (
) Each Employer Identiﬁcation Number (EIN) and plan number is treated as a separate unit in the population. (
) Mandatory review cases (IRM
, Mandatory and TEQMS Case paragraph
) are included in the population of cases that are subject to the TEQMS selection process. (

) At the beginning of each ﬁscal year, the TEQMS analyst determines the ap- proximate sample size of each group described above based on the number cases TE/GE expects to close during the year based on information from Sample Compliance, Planning and Classiﬁcation (CP&C) group. The TEQMS analyst calculates an annual sample size for each sample using statistical with a
% level of conﬁdence and plus/minus
% margin of error. Case review results are statistically valid at the national level; the TEQMS analyst computes the actual precision of the quality data at year-end. (
) The Compliance Planning and Classiﬁcation (CP&C) group is responsible selecting the TEQMS samples from cases closed during a We
TS cycle. TEQMS analyst monitors the sample selection during the year and requests adjustments to the rate, as appropriate, but only once per quarter. (
) QA reviewers review cases in a closed status then complete the survey. (
) The QA reviewer may return the case to the specialist based on their initial review under IRM
, Case Return Criteria Overview, after they the survey. (

) QA reviewers evaluate cases and complete a survey (electronic checksheet) that contains the case review criteria. The survey captures two types of Process mation: a. The administrative items, which contain case information, reviewer formation, and case return criteria. b. The quality standards/elements items, which contains quality standards, elements, aspects, and reason codes. Note: The survey for EP Merit cases contains only quality elements reason codes. (

) QA reviewers can ﬁnd the instructions to complete the surveys, and to apply the quality standards, elements, aspects and reason codes in the TEQMS - Tax Exempt Quality Measurement System - EP Determinations

) QA reviewers electronically submit the survey into the CVENT software database when they complete their case review. CVENT is a software licensing vendor used by IRS. (
) The database performs a series of validity checks before the system the survey’s data. (

) Each quarter, EP Determination and EP Merit surveys are summarized reports. The reports identify: a. Measures of overall performance on quality standards. b. Potential improvement areas. c. Feedback on speciﬁc root causes. d. Potential training needs. (
) The various reports do not provide individual, group or area evaluative mation. (
) The TEQMS analyst evaluates the database’s output and prepares trend reports. (

) The reports: a. Describe areas where EP Determinations has or has not done well. b. Provide suggestions for improvement. c. Analyze trends based on the answers on the survey. Note: Typically a separate report is prepared for EP Determination cases and
Typically a separate report is prepared for EP Determination cases and Merit cases, but a combined report is acceptable.

The BPMS requires case quality to be scored numerically. This measure is indicator of the IRS’s progress in achieving high-level strategic goals. offers a rating system that best measures the organization’s case quality. TEQMS is distinguished from the Critical Job Elements (CJE) Performance Plan. CJE Performance Plans are documents that describe to employees work performance expected of them and the performance standards applied their work performance. A manager’s case review should assess an strengths and weaknesses based on the CJE’s. Although the TEQMS standards are closely associated with the CJE’s, performance evaluation is based on TEQMS criteria. The computation of the organizational score is based on the reviewer’s answers as to whether the case met each standard (yes or no). EP tion cases have six quality standards. Some standards contain elements and/or aspects. The maximum possible score is
for a standard and/or element. EP Merit has ﬁve quality elements, which may contain reason The organization’s maximum possible score is also
See the TEQMS -
Employee Plans Determination Letter Program

Exempt Quality Measurement System - EP Determinations Student Guide, catalog number 86711Q, for more information about quality standards, elements and aspects at http://core.publish.no.irs.gov/trngpubs/pdf/t4317-002-- 2005-10-00.pdf.
The organizational quality score for all EP Determination cases = Total Number of Standards Passed / Total Number of Standards Rated X 100.
The organizational quality score for all EP Merit cases = Total Number of Elements Passed / Total Number of Elements Rated X 100.
Example 1:

During the ﬁscal year, TEQMS samples 400 EP Determination cases. The EP Determination survey has six quality standards. Therefore, the total number of standards rated equals 2,400 (400 x 6). Of the 2,400 standards rated, only 1,200 standards are passed (answered “Yes”).
The organizational quality score is 50 = (1,200 / 2,400 X 100).
Example 2:
During the ﬁscal year, TEQMS samples
EP Merit cases. The Merit case survey has ﬁve quality elements. Therefore, the total number of elements rated equals

elements rated,
elements are passed (answered “Yes”).
The organizational quality score is 90 = (1,800 / 2,000 X 100).

) To encourage greater consistency between reviewers in applying TEQMS criteria to cases, the Manager, EP Determinations QA does consistency reviews as needed. The TEQMS analyst schedules and administers these reviews. (

) The analyst selects at least one EP Determination case and at least one EP Merit case that each reviewer rates independently. Each reviewer prepares a survey with a speciﬁc case number and date the analyst gives. The analyst downloads each reviewer’s survey and prepares a summary of their answers. (

) The analyst schedules a meeting with reviewers to discuss the summary document, emphasizing the standards, elements and key aspects where reviewers differ. The goal is that the group will reach a consensus on the differ- ences. If this is not possible, the analyst notes it in a report and recommends appropriate action for reviewers, such as additional training or clariﬁcation of a procedure. (

) The analyst may prepare a report on the consistency review and forward it to the Manager, EP Determinations QA for approval. After approval, the analyst ﬁles the report and disseminates it as deemed appropriate. The group rotates reviewers as the primary reviewer on cases selected for the review for each
Exempt Quality Measurement System (TEQMS) 7.11.3 page
consistency review. The Manager, EP Determinations QA must note if the con- sistency review results indicate that additional training or improved procedures are required.
sistency review results indicate that additional training or improved are required. (

) This section describes: a. Criteria for returning cases to the specialist for further action. b. Instructions to the QA reviewers for returning TEQMS cases to ists. c. Type of feedback prohibited from TEQMS. (

) Reviewers return cases to specialists for further review with approval from management, if there is clear evidence that an incorrect determination has been reached. This applies when the qualiﬁcation of a retirement plan in a signiﬁcant negative impact on participants’ beneﬁts. Note: Cases with determination letter or user fee issues will be returned to the group for correction. (
) Cases are returned to the group under established guidelines, with QA gerial approval. The case is returned for correction and/or further a with a completed Form

, Reviewer’s Memorandum - TE/GE, Employee Plans Determinations, approved by the QA Manager. An email is sent to the group manager and the specialist, alerting them that the case requires addi- tional action. (
) If the specialist receives a case from QA, they should correct any issues complete a Form

, Response to Reviewer’s Memorandum - TE/GE, plaining corrections or disagreements with all of the reviewer listed issues. Email the form and corrected letters to the group manager for approval and ask that the form, letters and case information be forwarded to the QA Manager. (
) Reviewers may no longer give feedback on TEQMS cases because it is an “organizational” measure, not an individual, group or area performance
